description:
I love Stookey's club moderne! 

My Huband, I and some friends went for drinks last weekend. It was our first time there ( My husband and I) We really didn't know what to expect, and BOY were we in for a treat! 

First of all the bar is super stylish and vintage and steamline moderne!! Which I love!

the bar tenders wore white service jackets; AMAZING!
The drinks are good, and fair prices too.

Oh, and to top it off they have live music, and its vintage too. A really great trio led by a lady who also is vintage style.

All and all this place is awesome !
author: Ashley S.

description:
Good drinks, very rude bartenders.  Our bartender refused to describe a drink we were curious about "it's good, I wouldn't put anything on the menu I don't think is good".  Um okayyy, I guess I'll order it!  Turns out it tastes like vomit.  I felt awful already asking for something else, the bartender got so pissy and aggressive with us when I kindly asked to order a different one.  (The Bar was very slow at this time).  Although the drinks are good here, there's plenty of bars in the area that makes great drinks + great service. I do not recommend. 
- the drink was the Bull Shot.  Don't order this. Yak :) 
Gin, beef broth, lemon.
author: Kelsey E.

description:
I ended up here one night with a group of friends. The place was clearly designed by someone with attention to detail. If you like Art Deco, you'll enjoy whiling away some time here. Sitting and listening to vintage tunes playing over their PA, it was hard to tell what era I was in. Five stars for environs!

The only downer was when I went to order a drink. I have a sensitive and quirky palate, so I hate bitters like alcohol and grapefruit. I asked the younger bartender about what mocktails they could make, like maybe a shrub soda. He didn't know what that was, so he asked the older bartender.

That guy said they didn't make those, so I asked him what mocktails he could make, specifically without any grapefruit or pineapple juice. I know that most people like pineapple juice. I told you I have a quirky palate! He verified that I didn't want any alcohol and became unfriendly and dismissive.

I settled by ordering a Mexican coke when I really wanted a pretty drink I'd enjoy imbibing. I might end up here again if friends really want to go, but I'm not likely to suggest it. I travel for work and entertain customers, and I've been accommodated elsewhere with mocktails fitting my prerequisites.

If you love vintage and drink, you'll likely think this is a great place with classic cocktails. If you don't drink and attempt to order something not on the menu, I hope you get a friendlier reception!
author: Beth Ann G.

description:
I've been here a couple of times for a nite cap and I absolutely love this place for many reasons:

1) The vibe is chill and low-key
2) Great bartender
3) Awesome cocktail drinks
4) Good people watching

I definitely would recommend this place to my friends. I hope you give this wonderful cocktail bar a try. Cheers!

The simple things in life.
author: Owie N.

description:
A few friends and I were wandering the streets of San Francisco, looking for a plate to wet our whistles. While walking up (and I mean UP) Bush Street, we hear a man yelling out, "Come on in! We're open for business!"  Exchanging brief questioning looks, we decided to walk across the street and try this place out. 

To me, walking in felt like I had walked into a Gotham City bar (from the 90's animated series).  One look inside, especially after seeing the restroom doors, you'll probably agree (if you're an old dude like me). 

Anyway, we ended up being more than glad we stopped in. Our bartender was super friendly and super knowledgeable about tending the bar (he took exception to us referring to him as merely a mixologist). He explained, in a very polite way that a bartender is an individual with a passion for making great drinks and creating well-balanced experiences, as opposed to merely mixing drinks. Who am I to question a man in a white suit, well groomed and versed in drinks? 

Being a total newbie to mixed drinks (despite my age), I inquired as to the difference in alcohols and brands, mixers and mixed drinks.  He calmly and succinctly answered my many questions.  

He mixed up a mean Moscow Mule.  Next up, something called "Odin's Whiskers", which was equal parts sweet, strong and pleasant to drink. 

We really enjoyed stopping in to this place.  Check it out if you're ever in the area.
author: Rafael A.

description:
The concept gets a 5 the drinks get a 4 but the concept is so unique well no it's just executed so well that it overpowers the good but not out of this era drinks. 

I ended up here by accident. Place I was trying to go to was closed. I said fuck it let's go in here, you walk in and you think there's a dress code until I saw this bum ass couple in the center of the bar. The bartenders play the part though so don't worry about them. Drinks are strong...very strong, flavors are mmmkay. Their cider on tap was respectable, a nor cal local. 

Bathrooms use powder soup and their phone is spin dial haaa. Gotta love it.
author: Javier J.

description:
We ended up here by accident after grabbing some dinner in the neighborhood and were pleasantly surprised by this place. The bar is glowing with neon blue lights and takes you back in time. The place is small and cozy and the bartender had a uniform too. It's also very clean.

We got the pisco sour and oh it was so good. It was craft perfection and we loved every sip of it. The bartender is friendly and seems like the kind of person who is very knowledgeable about craft cocktails.

The bathroom had powdered soap which I found very amusing.
Definitely check this place out if you are in the area.
author: Preeti R.

description: Cool spot for very good and professionally prepared and served drinks. Bartenders first class.
author: R P.

description: This place has an art deco feel, huge selection of liquors, friendly bartender tonight. It's a cool place to have a drink with friends
author: Matthew S.

description: So we ventured in here since it was near the hotel.  Interesting. Definitely different, um service was good. I would say drinks were a little weak and small. I didn't handle the bill but I'm sure it wasn't too cheap. We had one round a split, the ambiance want quite what we were looking for that night.
author: Monique H.

description:
They have powdered soap. POWDERED SOAP!!! When was the last time you saw powdered soap?????

This bar with its glowing, blue neon lights, sets the scene like the 50s. The bartender wears a white button up with suspenders behind the diner-esque seating. Even the older patrons with their circular glasses and old school attire make you feel like you're in another era. 

Ordered some cocktails that were aite.
author: Angela L.

description: We used to frequent Stookey's because I like their cocktails, but a couple of months ago my friend and I stopped by and after waiting for almost 10 minutes and getting no service or acknowledgement from bartenders, who were not busy by the way but tried hard to look like they were, I will take my business elsewhere.
author: EG P.

description:
I went to this small bar on a whim and it did not disappoint. My bartender, Mitchell, is not merely a drink mixer, he is a passionate mixologist. It was fairly slow so I had a wonderful opportunity to chat with Mitchell about all things drink-related. 

I ordered a Mai Tai and Mitchell made it from scratch. The drink was superb. Mitchell also shared a half shot of Irish cream with me. It is made in-house daily and the flavor is insanely fresh. I've never had such a delicious Irish cream.

The drinks are delectable and the conversation and ambience were outstanding. You can't go wrong. Cheers!
author: Robyn R.

description:
The decor! So cool, like SpeakEasy era, 1920 feel, led lights and I love it!  Its different.  They call it Streamlined Moderne decor. The bartenders has a uniform too, so cute to match the theme.

I got a drink off the menu. Vodka and egg whites. First time that I got a purple drink. Very pretty and yummy.  Service with a smile therefore, what is there not to like?
author: Sandy B.

description:
We're not often in this part of town, but after any event at The Masonic center, this is a nice place to continue the night with well made drinks.  My wife prefers The Aviator.

Lines usually don't form here, so there is able seating.

Has a old timey pharmacist vibe with the bar tenders wearing white smocks
author: Marshall Y.

description:
We decided to stop by here for a quick after show drink after leaving the Masonic. The outside didn't really seem like much and I had low expectations because of it. Boy was I surprised when I stepped inside. Seriously one of the cleanest bar ever! I'm not even sure how it's humanly possible for a bar to be this clean. The interior is pretty nice as it is a fusion of hipster and 1930s era. I noticed the bartender had a nice hipster mustache and a white coat and I knew our drink would be craft perfection. Lol seriously though, he seems like he's the type that would take a lot of pride in his drinks, therefore would put the effort into making it great.

It took awhile for the bar back to take our order as he had to attend to others first. There seems to be just the duo running the bar, so a bit of a wait is expected even if it's not fully packed. The drinks we had were pretty good, but I really enjoyed the ambiance and cleanliness of the place. It also wasn't crazy loud so it's a great place to chat with friends. I'd definitely stop by here again when I'm in the area.
author: Linh H.

description:
Very good drinks and good service. The place is extremely small (with a small bar and a few small tables), like NYC bar small, a rarity I've found while living out here. It's very old school inside; reminds me of that classic "Nighthawks" painting for some reason. A lot of different drinks (NY Sour has the egg white, which is always a plus), but not a ton of variety on the bourbon side, which is my libation of choice. They make the standard Sazarac, etc, but thought they would have a little diversity with that particular spirit. Oh well, I had a few other non-bourbon cocktails that were good. 

Since it's small, and since SF is rarely coal-oven humid/hot like the entire Bay Area was on Labor Day weekend, this place was a sauna a few Fridays ago. Not the bar's fault, but just know if it's a hot day, it'll be hotter inside. Don't let this sully your opinion of the place though--very good, and recommended.
author: Dan M.

description: My friend and I wandered into this bar after a comedy show one night, I believe it was a Thursday. There were a few people in there and we came in and sat at the bar. The bartender asked for our ID's. My friend and I are 27 years old and we are travel nurses so we had IDs from our home state. The bartender accepted both of our IDs at first. Walked away and then came back. I then tried to order a beer and he came back over to my friend and asked her to show her ID again. He quizzed her on her birthday and her address and where in Pennsylvania she was from. She's from Johnstown, PA, ever heard of it sir?? I honestly thought he was joking. I told him we are literally old enough to save lives on the daily. Also why all of a sudden did you change your mind on accepting her ID? He proceeded to be like "well her ID is fake" and refused to serve us. Don't know what his problem was because the ID wasn't expired and it definitely wasn't fake. I don't even think people use fake IDs anymore. *shrugs*. We ended up getting really tasty drinks over at PCH anyways.
author: Margo B.

description:
My new place to go for the best cocktail drinks. With special events featuring local jazz bands I'm never tired coming back.

The best part is the atmosphere - relatively quite, so you can keep a conversation without yelling in our person's ear.

The crowd is also something special - come here on a special night to see people dressed up like 40s, unforgettable!
author: Vladimir G.

description:
When a bartender from the Bourbon & Branch group plus the staff from Michelin-rated Sons & Daughters recommends this place you know it's gonna be good.

Set in a revamped corner diner, Stookey's serves Cuban classics & other craft cocktails complete with a jazzy 45" record "DJ".  Small, intimate, & swanky... don't blink or you'll miss it!

Awesome!!!
author: Lyne B.

description: I wish I was a local because I would be in here all the time. Charming music from the 40s was playing, chrome was shining, and a friendly older gentleman wearing a white coat made me a beautiful pisco sour. I came in at a slow time, but I could see this small place getting crowded very quickly.
author: Zach C.

description: Showed up at 8 or so on a very slow Monday night and bartender Ren was fantastic and knowledgeable company. The place is a time-travel jewel box and transports you magically to the 1920s. Every detail of this small place has been carefully thought out. The fun and interesting period drinks are a value too in the SF market. Wish they had some food bites, but they are wonderful at what they do, do.
author: Ward W.

description:
Stookey's is a nice middle ground between the dives in this region of the forest and the not-so-divey. They do simple cocktails with only a little pomp and circumstance - sure, the bartender wear bowties and shop coats, but they don't go through the theater of lighting stuff on fire for kicks. Seems like a chill staff, too.

Crowd's quiet and cheerful. Stookey's is too uphill to pull tourists, I guess, and too small and humble to pull in the after work crowd. 

Music's nice, maybe a little cliché. I like La Vie En Rose as much as the next, but hearing it once or twice a night is a little much. Then again, I guess that's just their deal. They've got a hat rack. Stand in your truth, Stookey's.

Makes a great high/low pairing with White Horse around the corner.
author: Jim M.

description: If you are in the city on a Thursday night, this is great little spot for live music and a solid drink. From the minute we walked in, I was immediately drawn in by the vintage vibe and cool music. People were dressed up in old school suits and some folks were even dancing. And the drinks were stellar! I had a barrel aged concoction that was similar to a Manhattan. I ask the bartender for a recommendation and it was on point. Watching them behind the bar, the bartenders definitely know what they are doing. The music created a nice and classy atmosphere for almost any occasion. Live music is only Thursday nights, 7:30-10PM. Visit then, you won't be disappointed.
author: John N.

description: Stookey's is my favorite place to enjoy a quiet drink in the city. The decor transports you back to the Art Deco era. The bartenders can make all the classic drinks and are a joy to watch. For me, a trip to San Francisco isn't complete without a visit to Stookey's.
author: Carlos R.

description: We had some friends recommend that we stop here for cocktails, and it was so much fun!! The staff were so friendly and made us custom drinks that were so good. The piano player was very talented, and the 50's vibe made it really enjoyable and different. Definitely stop here for a cocktail during your stay.
author: Kristin P.

description:
Drinks were great, the staff was really nice, and I dig cute smaller space. We sat a table of 3, four would be tough - this is not a big place.

I got a Mai Tai and a "100 Reasons Rye," I'd recommend both, although I've seen the 100 Reasons show positively in more reviews. In general, I don't think you can go wrong. The atmosphere and cocktails were great, prices were what I expected, would recommend for a smaller group, or meeting up with a friend.
author: Pam S.

description:
Bartender with handle bar mustache is a complete jerk. If you aren't dressed in the 30's theme clothing, you're basically scum in this place. Boring live music, staunchy customer base and horribly rude bartenders that apparently think it's okay to ignore a bride and groom on their wedding night (in their wedding attire and all the customers clapped congratulations, so no mistake was made that it was their wedding night.) 

Anyway, 
We will not be returning to this drab, rude, and hilariously snooty bar again.
author: Hayley A.

description:
I came here with my friend and his girlfriend to get a drink before a show at the Masonic.  We had checked out a few other places nearby but the wait was too long and this place had seats at the bar.  I'm fairly happy we did, this is a very sleek bar done up in the art-deco influenced aesthetic of the 1920s and 30s.  The bartenders are sharply dressed and they mix up some tasty cocktails.  

I can never recall the names but I had two tasty drinks, one featuring rye and orange bitters and the second a bourbon and absinthe concotion.  Was quite pleased with both and really liked the setting. Will be back!
author: Alan S.

description:
Been here a handful of times and it's normally been good but I had a bad experience last night with one of the bartenders. The portly one with the round glasses and hipster waxed mustache. I asked for a vodka martini with Kettle One. He said we don't have Kettle One. No problem, but what do you have I asked? He pointed a couple of bottles in the wall. I said I can't read the labels because my eyesight is bad, and asked what they were. He then said, in a condescending tone, "with vodka it doesn't really matter" and walked away. What a dick! And I completely disagree. In a vodka martini, you can definitely taste the vodka. 

This bar is too small and I don't want to deal with the jerk-off bartender again so I obviously won't be going back.
author: Andrew F.

description:
Honest pours on the liquors served straight up, moderate prices as well for the location. Amazing Irish coffee topped with a heavenly layer of cream served in adorable glass. Unique cocktails as well that taste nothing like they appear: 12 Mile Limit, 20th Century. They even offer fizzes. 

The best part about this place is the small venue space built out like a boozy soda fountain shop, think a speakeasy combined with Johnny Rockets (I'm sure there is a better comparison, but that's what comes to mind when I describe to friends and family). Relaxed atmosphere that never rages above comfortable speaking levels. The bartender is incredibly friendly and will make personal suggestions based on preferences. Great neighborhood bar away from the chaos of the Union Square/Tenderloin crowds and madness.
author: Alison A.

description: Great bar and drinks. Place is small but never too crowded. I love how there's always room to sit here and it doesn't get too crowded. Perfect for small groups. Only negative is that the drinks do take a while to make.
author: Lisa T.

description: Came here with a girlfriend for some after happy hour drinks. This place is super small, just the bar area with a few tables. Very nice atmosphere though, feels like an old school diner. Friendly bartenders who wipe up some pretty tasty concoctions. Would return, wish drinks were a little less pricey though... haha, but that's all of SF.
author: Marie D.

description: Stookey's, where have you been all my life? I'm scared to write a review because I know it will mean more patrons, but this place deserves it. Stookey's is fairly non-descript on the outside, but when you walk in, you're walking back in time. Retro countertops and tables, bartenders with aprons, and old-school cocktails of all sorts await you. I really, really like this place because you won't get a bunch of raucous TL patrons; what you will get are drinks from a bygone era, like the Bullshot ($12) and its delicious mix of beef bouillon, gin, celery salt, and tabasco. Think it sounds gross? Try it. You'll thank me later.
author: Danny C.

description: Stookey's is, hands down, the best cocktail bar in SF. Most of their cocktails are classics (I recommend the Twentieth Century Cocktail), with a few modern takes thrown in for good measure. The space is small and intimate, and it's relatively easy to get a spot at the bar or a table. The bartenders, including Mr. Stookey himself, are walking alcoholic encyclopedias. If you're a booze nerd, this is the place for you.
author: Dan B.

description:
This place is bright for a bar and I liked that. Something different than most bars and lounges. I actually thought it was an ice cream shop or candy store at first sight. It seemed so clean.

I could tell the drinks were of high quality, and the ones I tried were all pretty good. The prices are higher than average for the area, but that reflect quality - no hangover the next day quality.

Our bartender was nice and engaging in conversation. It was also probably due to how empty the place was on a Tuesday night. Maybe like me, most people have not heard of it to check it out. I would add this to my rotation if in the area.
author: Peter L.

description:
My coworker who lives in this neighborhood suggested I check out Stookey's since I wanted a chill bar that wasn't too crowded. I stopped by to meet up Peter L and a friend on Tuesday, November 24th at 5:45pm. Luckily I made it in time for happy hour 4:30pm-6pm, $2 off all cocktails, $1 off beer & wine.

*100 reasons rye: james pepper rye, punt e mes, cointreau, regan's orange bitters (originally $13, happy hour $11)
*Whiskey smash: evan williams 1783 bourbon, fresh lemon juice, senor curacao, stone fruit, mint ($13)
*Pisco punch: barsol pisco, fresh lemon and lime juices, pineapple juice, pineapple syrup ($12)
*Lion's tail

I enjoyed the 100 reasons rye. Perfect for me as I like my cocktails dark and boozy. For my second drink, I got the Lion's tail. I asked the bartender to make me a good follow up and this was perfect! I can't remember what was in it, but it was slightly lighter than my first drink. Even though I like my drinks stronger as the night goes on, this somehow worked.

The bar is fairly small, but it wasn't crowded at all. There was only one other patron when I got there. It's a little bright and the art deco theme kind of makes me feel like I'm in a diner, but I liked the drinks. The bartender was also super friendly.

Good place to start off the night. If you can, make sure to get there before 6pm for their HH specials.
author: Elena N.

description:
1920's diner with classic drinks as well as new ones. 

the bartender are even dressed and suited like the olden days in the white vest and attire. so cute!

Nice honest pours. Bartenders are knowledgeable and seem they really like their jobs. 

I ordered a french 75 and I have to say, it's the best french 75 i've had yet. it was beautiful to the eyes and tasty for the tongue. 

it's small and cozy. nice and quite. 

Great atmosphere for first dates.
author: Leme K.

description: Very cute little bar, wonderful, creative cocktails, and nice chill atmosphere. You can tell that a lot of thought was put into the decor (it's a 1930's themed bar.) If you like fancy cocktails that you probably would never make for yourself at home, check out Stookey's. The drink menu has a lot of variety. You'll definitely want to try a few different cocktails before leaving! I have been in a few times and always received friendly service.
author: Liz M.

description: Service = Amazing. Cocktails = Amazing. What else are you asking for at a bar? SF friends brought us here for drinks before dinner on a Tuesday, and I returned the next day to order 2 more of the same cocktail I had the night prior before catching a red eye flight back home. Get the "Bullshot" and don't ask questions. As an avid soup lover I felt compelled to order this strange drink that contained beef broth while doubting that I would actually enjoy it. IT WAS SO GOOD. I loved the saltiness of whatever they put on the rim and the pickled pearl onions garnished on a toothpick.
author: Justine H.

description: Always enjoy grabbing a quick beer or cocktail here before heading out for dinner or after a long workday. They often showcase local jazz bands as live entertainment, which is super cool! Decent prices on draft beer. Definitely swing by Stookey's for a drink!
author: Peter C.

description: What a great place!  Yummy cocktails and great ambiance. Friendly service in such a cool place. Worth checking out and coming back for sure.
author: Griffin C.

description:
YES. YES. YES.
Why did I not come here earlier? I've passed by Stookey's Club Moderne a million times while walking home and it was always one of those "oh, we need to check that out soon" places that I would forget about later - not anymore, this is now on a top list of places to go to enjoy myself and a great cocktail. 

DRINKS:
My boyfriend and I enjoyed some great cocktails here - 
100 Reasons Rye ($13) - delicious, nice balance and a hint of smoke from the flame on the lemon swath. 
Aviation ($11) - this is possibly my favorite classic cocktail and this one was fantastic, perfectly balanced and the prohibition era style glasses these drinks are served in really just add a nice touch to the whole place
20th Century ($11) - perfect, another great classic cocktail, refreshing and tart. 

ATMOSPHERE/SERVICE:
This is a fun little time travel in nob hill. The whole bar is immaculate in its design, clean lines, and dim neon lighting. You really feel like you're in an old soda shop... but with booze! The bartenders are friendly, attentive, and knowledgeable about the cocktail program. This place is small, but the layout is nice, 10-12 bar seats and small booth/tables lining the outer wall that I could just cozy up in all night and enjoy. 

reading other reviews, looks like I just missed the happy hour here so next time I'll try and make it before 6:00PM to get that deal. In all, this place is outstanding. Service is excellent, prices (for the area and high quality cocktails) are very reasonable and the overall experience is better than the standard bars you find in the area, I'll be coming back here more in the future!
author: Kelsey B.

description: Great atmosphere of a speakeasy. Intimate. Period-Deco design and music. Very cool cocktails. Intriguing list of drinks and bartenders who are happy (and skilled) to make something special for you. Met the owners who were there one night. Fully committed to keeping this a prime stop for anyone who wants a bit of style in their evening. A must go-to!
author: Doug B.

description: They accept bitcoin. What more do you need to know? Go to the bar and ask to pay in bitcoin. Join the 21st century already.
author: Evan D.

description:
Summary: Fun, themed bar with delicious drinks and a classy-casual ambiance. Good for nights when you want a more laid-back atmosphere.

Pros:
- Bar is themed very well throughout (from the drinks, to the glassware, to the space, to the bartenders' outfits, etc).
- Bartenders are friendly.
- Laid-back, mellow atmosphere.
- Prices are about on-par with other similar bars.

Cons:
- Neighborhood is a bit rough (though maybe this helps keep the party crowd away?).
author: Brandon C.

description: Step back in time for a crafted cocktail --great retro experience where the bartenders wear white jackets and dole out amazing libations
author: Darryl N.

description:
I nearly blew my wig when I discovered Stookey's Club Moderne. This booze tribute to the 1930s is straight up my alley!

Whether youse a pip or a pill, a joe or a wheat, a pally or a moll, there's some good giggle juice here to pitch plenty woo to your tastebuds. Ain't no Mickey Finns here, just keenly made smooth libations. If I weren't so beat, I'd be spendin' my salad here every night. 

Try the Liberal, a tribute to FDR, or the New York Sour (my favorite) with a dash of cabernet atop an egg white foam.

Tog yourself to the bricks, not because you have to dress up, but because it's more fun to look aces. Ring-a-ding-ding!

(Translation: Good bar. Friendly service. Awesome drinks. I'm poor.)
author: Keane L.

description: This place just became my favorite new bar for amazing swag drinks in SF! I remember seeing Stookey's Club Moderne from the street while walking one night and thinking ...'this is the place that gets a solid 4+ stars on the Yelp scale?!' I just didn't think it looked like much! Yet in all my glorious, curious fashion to find what's amazing in my home city or one's that I frequent, I had to check it out. Upon entering Stookey's one feels that they are zipped all the way back to the post prohibition 1930's! I liked it immediately! The music was if that era and the decor was too.. even the bartenders were clothed in the fashion of that era. The drinks here aren't for the wallet conscious, but is anything in SF, really? Lucky enough to sit right up at the bar, I got to witness drinks being concocted with ease and flair, precision and grace. Much thought was placed into garnishment and the finishings of what looked like a perfect drink from my vantage point! BUT, one swipe of an orange peel ever so slight over the rim of an antique glass and I am learning the care these bartenders placed into each and every cocktail they artistically created. The bar was clean too.. NO mess of liquor sloshings all over a sticky back bar, ( I KNOW you KNOW what I am talking about.. because anyone that's been to a busy bar has seen that , and frankly that's hygienically , UN-hygienically gross.. how did any of us survive our drunk college 20's?!!) None of that here.. and even better, the very busy bartenders are nice and helpful to people like me that question ALL kinds of drinks. This place could easily be one of those snooty Nob Hill Union Square places .. I didn't witness that. They do a perfectly beautiful French 75 , (my choice), with just enough tart and just enough sparkling.. and it's not put into a martini glass. It's put into a beautiful antique glass that will likely remind you of your wealthy grandmother who had a million of these tucked away for cordials and the like! There is a cocktail of the month too .. January it's fittingly called , The Liberal. Oh SF! I had one of these amazing French 75 drinks .. and small with a kick that can sneak up on you is what I would call it.. I went back to my ever trusting champagne and yes, I did let my studious Charlie Chaplin look alike bartender with round eye glasses down with that order .. but that's okay.. I will be back to this place that pops you back to an era we have long forgotten ... but, not quite.. Thanks to Stookey's for that ! Cheers!
author: Kimberly V.

description: Such a snappy little Art Deco bar! Just happened to be in the area and found this little gem! So glad I did!
author: Jeramiah C.

description: A real bar with real drinks and no other nonsense. It's perfect. Come and have a drink or three. Gin's an especially good place to start, but all the cocktails are finely balanced and truly aimed.
author: Nicolas G.

description: Omg this place is fantastic! Cozy music and crafty cocktails. Definitely I'll come back.
author: Kyoko U.

description:
We've come here sporadically since the bar opened because it's a great location for meeting people and you can have a conversation with people without screaming. The vibe is very retro and cool, and we like all of the small details like the light fixtures and old-fashioned coupes. The bar is never super crowded and we can usually get a spot at the bar. The bartenders are friendly but I wouldn't say they are necessarily attentive. We really appreciate their variety of traditional cocktails, like the Aviation and Gin Fizz. Between my husband and I, we've probably tried all of the drinks on the menu; my husband prefers the whiskey and tiki-esque drinks, and I'm partial to the gin and punch drinks. 

The few things that keep me from coming here more often: 1. the bar has a bit of a sterile feel to it that can't really be explained. Perhaps it's too new and needs to be "lived-in" more? 2. the bathroom has a bit of a flushing problem. I've definitely had to let the bartender know more than once that the toilet wasn't flushing. Beyond those things, this bar is definitely worth checking out; it's a casual, yet classy spot for both group hangouts and dates.
author: Regina L.

description:
An impeccable bar and drinking experience. Stookey's is the only bar to have successful transported me back in time to another era and, along with that, nail the ever elusive Aviation cocktail (very few bartenders in SF know how to make it well). This review is almost a year overdue, but well watered with back-to-back great times at this establishment! 

Stop reading and get here in a hurry!
author: Alita M.

description:
LOVE everything about this place!
The décor is fantastic, it makes you feel like you're in Miami. ( I love art deco.)

The bartenders are fast, and still pleasant. 

Even when it was packed, you could still have a conversation without screaming.

Drinks are well made,balanced, and only fresh quality ingredients are used.

A true gem of a bar!
author: Amanda G.

description: This place is legit. If you like a damn good cocktail, check it out. Nuff said. PS Aaron really knows his stuff.
author: Sonja N.

description:
I truly loved this place! The atmosphere is similar to that of a Mad Men episode. The two men working that night even looked the part which added to the experience. The glassware took me back to fancy holiday dinners at my grandparents house, drinking cider out of their vintage crystal glasses. 
I was pretty excited to see an Old Cuban on the menu, as I've only been a few places with this drink displayed and it's always a favorite. It didn't disappoint! I had two (maybe three?). 
The bartender was friendly and by the time we left this place was packed! 
It looks like Stookey's Club Moderne is doing pretty well, hopefully it becomes a staple in the city!
author: Brianna H.

description: This bar was amazing! I loved the style of it, the bartender was attentive and great, even met the co-owner and he was beyond great! Definitely a place to visit!
author: Ray H.

description: Beautiful and delicious cocktails created with incredible care. So grateful to have such a wonderful spot in the neighborhood. It's like stepping into an old Humphrey Bogart move scene. I always love it.
author: Patrique R.

description: Mixed feelings on this spot but I will give it the benefit of the doubt. I'm only a couple blocks away and so maybe that tilts it to 4 stars. It aims to be reminiscent of a 50s style cocktail bar and I think on that note it hits it beautifully.
author: Leo I.

description: Great little spot to get drinks before seeing a show at Masonic! Great service and the bar tender made me drinks not on the menu. Quick service, too!
author: N A.

description: The place has an interesting decor, very Art Deco. The drinks here aren't as cool as the decor. We ordered two drinks each and no one liked their drinks. Too bad because the bar mender was nice.
author: Alice W.

description: Pretty great newish place just on nob hill. Suited cocktail mixologist check. Cool 1930s feel and music check. Great cocktails of course. Even a decent IPA on tap for when you want a frosty. Go now to check this place out.
author: Andres B.

description: If you are in the SF area, this place is a must try. Dude with the handlebar mustache made some killer drinks. The live music was spectacular, and the overall atmosphere of this cocktail bar was incomparable to any experience I've had thus far. Don't be shy about showing up in your favorite 1930s attire (to be fair, we did not, but if I had known of this place ahead of time...). The drinks are delicious, and the ambience only heightens the experience. Spend enough time here and you could convince yourself of time travel.
author: Cassidy B.

description:
This is a great bar.  I love the theme of post-prohibition.  Every detail in the place is a replica of a bar in 1934.

This place makes some great fancy cocktails.  My favorite was the Pan America Clipper.  This cocktail stays true to the bar's theme because this cocktail dates back to 1930's post-prohibition.  All served in the glassware that the same cocktail would have been served to you in 1934.  The menu is a limited, and I wish they had just a few more of the fancy and unique cocktails.  They also have wine and a list of liquors to choose from if you decide to forgo the fancy cocktails.   I'm excited to come back and try the Irish Coffee on a cold night!

They have Happy Hour is everyday from 4:30 - 6:00.  

Oh, and make sure to ask the bartender about the "Doctor is in" sign when you go!
author: Rose Z.

description:
Small, tight bar with a solid old school, Johnny Rocket, Back 2 the Future vibe to it. The bartenders are all dressed up and the cocktails are pretty decent. 

If you're sitting there sipping away and confronted with memories of pirate ships and beer...you're not crazy. This used to be a piratey-dive bar and went under a serious make over. I'd drop by again in the area for a decent cocktail.
author: Jonathan Y.

description:
We stopped by here on a whim not long after they opened and were struck by the exclusivity of the place (we felt like we were walking into a small private party- not totally welcomed) and the odd decor.  As for the latter, while I understand the vibe the owners were going for, the outcome is much more 50's diner than 30's bar.  The lighting really needs to be turned down. A lot. 

Every drink we'd tried from the list of cocktails was well made and if you like sazeracs, this would be the place to visit.  But that said, Stookey's is still pretty underwhelming due to the ambiance (or lack of it) and I'd prefer Comstock Saloon if looking for a throwback experience with excellent drinks to boot.
author: Joanne G.

description:
I really love a good cocktail -- those tasty combination of flavors that impart a warm glow. I like beautiful design. I also like a cosy place I can feel comfortable and welcome. I find this all at Stookey's! Between the super nice bartenders, the lovely atmosphere, the sound of lively conversation, and a well-made cocktail to savor, the long work day fades gently like a distant memory. 

If you like a noisy crowd, blarring televisions, the smell of stale bar, and drinks that burn through your stomach like lighter fluid, then Stookey's might not be your place. 

What else can I say about Stookey's Club Moderne except it combines elegance with a comfy, inviting atmosphere and damn good drinks! Love love love it!!!!!
author: Aimee M.

description:
The first time I walked into Stookey's I was struck with a sense of nostalgia for a place and time I could have never experienced.  The bar is crafted flawlessly from the porthole door windows in- to the tables and stools at the bar as the total 30's experience.  Even the phone on the bar is a classic.  The music selection contributes to the mood in this dimly lit throwback bar.  I've got to admit it's very well done through and through.  Even the bartenders play a role in their white coats, helping you forget that beyond their doors lay a totally different world. 

That being said, I'm not one for fancy cocktails, but everything I've tried thus far has been good, and contributed nicely to my time-traveling experience.  Seth was very helpful and I've been back a few times since... I just wish they had food, they'd see me more often.
author: Jesse G.

description:
drink: love love love. The bartender was awesome and knowledgeable. He was just really nice and professional. Christ hard to find ones without a permanent snobby bitch face serving the rich only. 

place: chill, art deco, brings you to a different place. pretty cool.
author: P L.

description: Cool looking place with great setting and good drinks but bartenders ruined it. They only coversed with thenselves. Though we sat at the bar in front of them, they ignored us. Finally we asked them was it ok to order. If they had been friendly and welcoming, the place would have been a home run.
author: Lisa S.

description:
Giving four stars because I don't want to get too enthusiastic too soon. But let me just say--so cute inside, nice and quiet, GREAT bartenders, amazing glassware and great feel. I tentatively love it here and am excited to have a neighborhood bar again. 

Note: it's not dark or musical or hip. Don't bring dates here to impress them. Being people you want to chat with.
author: Vivienne P.

description: Just stumbled over this place and one look inside I had to try a cocktail. It's like slipping into the past. Affordable indulgence set in a classy 50's throwback. Drinks are perfectly made of high quality mixers and friendly atmosphere. Recently opened, I do hope it takes off as I would love to come back for 100 Reasons Rye.
author: Rob B.

description: This bar is everything I had hoped it would be: a place for conversation, clean cocktail flavors (lots of citrus and anise without too much sweetness), and simple style.
author: David S.

description:
Very nice little bar, cool art deco decor, I would say swanky b/c it's not a dive, but people did not dress up (casual, not trashy dress).

My friend's Mai Tai was very strong!

I wasn't too fond of the taste of the sloe gin fizz, but it was something different for me to try, since I had never had a drink with pasterized egg whites.
author: N. F.

description: The coolest place in San Francisco, hands down. A great homage to the 1940s with old school tunes and spot on decor. Cool bar tenders that are extremely interpersonal and knowledgeable of cocktails. Highly recommend to anyone here whether they're local or visiting from out of town.
author: Bryan I.

description: Wife and I stopped in here on the way to BART from the Masonic. It's small, dark and will get packed quick. But the drinks were wicked good. They were out of Pisco by 9pm? But the fizz we had made up for it. Worth the stop.
author: Brian H.

description: Bartenders are very friendly, creative, make GREAT drinks! Music is classic. The jams. Retro setting. Love this place - set up like a diner except no food. Not complaining. Will bring everyone back.
author: Wendy K.

description: Bartender her was fantastic, made me an Aviation Cocktail (which I had always wanted to try) and said if I don't love it he'll drink it. One of the best cocktails I've had hands down. Also very knowledgeable and willing to explain stuff. Try the Pisco Punch!
author: Emanuel C.

description:
Stookey's is essentially what you want in a cocktail bar. For the decor: imagine the game Bioshock without the impending chaos. (e.g. 1920s conveyed very well). The bartenders are true artists with their craft and are friendly and open to let you try small amounts of new liqueurs etc. that you may be new to. The environment is relaxed, not loud, ideal for a small party to just come and lounge over some great drinks. Not too much seating but you don't need it in a place like this. You can easily strike up a conversation with your neighbour (whether they're in your party or not) and have a focused and real conversation. No TVs to distract. 

Big fan of the southside cocktail. It's like an augmented G&T.

Don't forget to get the fernet flight!
author: Devin C.

description:
The ambiance here is awesome. It's a retro vision of the future (e.g. something that someone in the 70s might imagine 2016 to look like). It's not exactly one of those new-agey craft cocktail bars with a million ingredients and a thousand odd infusions to consider. Instead, the drinks are all classic (but there are a lot to choose from!) and extremely well executed. 

The bar itself lends itself to good conversation, so definitely come here if you're new in town or just looking to make new friends with interesting people (and not the usual ex-frat financial district ilk that usually lurk around nob hill bars). Also, spend some time chatting with the bartender (owner?). He's a calm and relaxing presence. The bar feels old school in the best of ways - the bartender is not the untouchable, moustached hipster of most SF bars and more of the calming but professional presence. And one that makes a damn fine cocktail.
author: Sylvia L.

description: Best drink i've had...ever (the zaragosa). Cool old-school vibe. A meticulous and awesome bartender and another one with perfect recommendations. Pleasantly surprised and impressed customers rn!
author: Danielle D.

description: Fabulous deco old timey craft cocktail bar!  Expansive cocktail list that if you like, you never have to drink the same thing twice!  I love the decor and 20's-30's post prohibition vibe.  You feel a little transported and not just because you're drinking!  Nob hill adjacent, Union Square...is spitting distance...cmon in, the drinking is fine!
author: Darby W.

description:
I don't want to write a review because I don't want you all going there and spoiling it for me. Or making it too crowded or whatever. So don't go...unless you're someone I'd like talking to.

Everything was good and classic. Great cocktails without too much artisan, frou frou, "stuff" in them. A great find near the typically disappointing Union Square.
author: Goodbye K.

description:
Club Moderne features beautifully-made cocktails. This is one of the best Negronis I have ever had, and I've had many - from dad's homestyle fizzy ones to the classic Excelsior Campari Cocktail. CM is not really a place to slam down 4 or 5 drinks - you'll pay a cool hun if you're a decent tipper - but savoring is part of the magic in this beautifully-designed, deco-moderne location. The owners are senior members of the Art Deco Society. All staff wear white tux jackets, and the fixtures and lighting are subtly spectacular; a graphic designer's dream.

The first time we went in, a Wednesday at perhaps 9:30, we sat down at a table to take things in. Seth came over, gave us a drink menu, and spoke with us for a long time. Last night we went in again - I arrived first - and sat down and waited. It was a little busier, two bartenders and no table service that time. Club Moderne is intimate - it gets quite loud very easily, but there was someone very very loud there. I think it was the ghost of F. Scott.
author: Roxmarie M.

description:
Step into a time portal. This place is very unassuming on the outside. Be sure to take a peak in. It's hard to realize that this actually a super cool speakeasy with a clean old-fashioned style, great for all folks.

Bartender made me a great personal special twist on a classic Rye Manhattan, just what I was looking for. Yum. Can't wait to bring my co-workers over.
author: Matt S.

description: This place is almost great. The service and drinks are incredible!! But the ambiance concept is strongly felt, but u fortunately lacking, but there is a great idea behind it so I hope someone will read this and consider improvements. Instead, I feel compelled to suggest darker paint, especially for the ceiling, and throwing away the light wood with teal chairs that are at most of the tables. They clash with the benches and are the wrong style. And maybe throw in a kitschy throwback jukebox, or something else kitschy, to loosen the place up.
author: Valerie Z.

description:
Why?  I'll give you 100 Reasons Rye!  That's all you need to know.  

Amazing cocktails made in a cozy club that throws you back to a different time.  

I love this place!
author: R. B.

description:
A real neighborhood gem. I hesitate to review it because I actually hope it stays hidden. The other 5 star reviews have it right, so I won't repeat them.

I hope the reviewers with complaints about the drinks being too strong or the place not being packed full of young people have found their way to the Marina.
author: Sean F.

description: I love this place. As soon as you come in it seems like you travel in time. Very private , great bartenders, for sure id come back.
author: Simon B.

description: Cocktails here were solid. But honestly the vibe isn't great (feels a bit cold and stiff), which I found surprising given the previous reviews. I guess I would say that for this level of cocktail is San Francisco, I would prefer the vibe of many other places.
author: Amjad S.

description: I'm literally sitting here right now and receiving the worst service. I asked one of the servers at the bar who was on his phone to put an order in for us. He was playing on his phone and reluctantly agreed. Guess what it's 30 minutes later and the bartender never received our order. Step your game up or you won't make it. The sad thing is this place isn't even that busy, so it's really not a huge hassle to put a drink order in for us. Additionally, I tried to close my tab and my waiter told me to wait while he unloads the dishwasher, unbelievable. Two stars because the decor is cool. Never coming back.
author: Alex L.

description: I love this place, and not just because it's in walking distance. The cocktails are inspired and phenomenal. However, what makes it especially unique is how serious the bartenders take their craft. Solario brought his own vintage cocktail mixing kit, in a leather case(I got to observe him as he came on his shift.). I was in awe, just watching him. Ever see someone actually care about their craft? This dude does, and the drinks reflect that. I love drinks where you can taste the booze, and that reflect my personal tastes for bourbon and whiskey. I recommend the Derby(I ask for marinated boozy craft cherries to be added), and the 100 Reasons Rye. They have drinks to suit every taste, and the atmosphere is friendly and upscale, yet not pretentious. I expect pretension in a place that is modelled after a post-prohibition, late 1930's bar, but honestly- it's full of the friendliest people and imaginative drinks at typical San Francisco cocktail prices. Nice selection of alcohol, including fernet(not a fan- I'm a scotch/bourbon girl). This bar is an experience and I love the vibe here. Hell, one night, a guy who was in the band Tool was enjoying drinks, and was also praising the bar. Definitely one of my neighborhood fav watering holes.
author: Robin W.

description: Hmm no welcome, no service, finally placed an order, half an hour later nobody is making the drinks and we have to reorder our drinks while two people are just standing around socializing and only one guy is slowly "working". Freakin infuriating. This is a Friday night at 10pm. You're either clearly discriminating based on our ethnicity or you DGAF or both.
author: Sandy T.

description:
Came here on a random Tuesday night with my girlfriend a few days ago to check out something different. It's around the holidays in SF so I expected a lazier Tuesday night compared to the average. But we were cool with that.

The ambience at Stookey's stays true to the post-prohibition vibe it sets out to convey. The barkeep made great old-school cocktails in a white uniform. The drinks menu oozed 1930s-1940s flavors and all of the liquors behind the bar also stayed true to their theme. The lighting is a lot brighter than I'd expect at a bar but I'm guessing indicative of the times.

All in all a great place to chat with a friend or girlfriend and feel like you've been transported to a different time with good drinks. Plan on going down the list of drinks eventually. 

The 100 reasons rye and negroni were spot on. (First 2 drinks on the menu)
author: Win R.

description:
Let me open this review by stating that I was a HUGE fan of The Royal Tug, from its decor and music to the drinks and bartenders.  It was my local and I held out hope that Club Moderne could fill the (very large) shoes left.

I finally had time to visit the latest iteration of a bar on the corner of Bush and Taylor last night.  I had high hopes as the era of which is is reminiscent is my favorite and with the Presidio Social Club pedigree of the team behind it, I was certain the cocktails would be stellar.

Let's start with the cocktails.  My companion had a Manhattan and I had a Sazerac.  They were both stellar.  No doubt about the quality of the drink program here, and at $12.50 a pop, in line from a cost perspective.  There were two bartenders working, a very nice woman and a stoic man who seemed to have checked his friendly demeanor at the door.  They could have done with just one bartender as I think there were only about six or seven people there on a Friday night around midnight.

If well-concocted cocktails were all that mattered at a bar, Club Moderne would get an entirely different review from me, but as we all know, it's often less about the cocktails and more about the ambiance.  This is where Club Moderne completely falls down.

Trying to be "post-Prohibition" themed (1930s/40s) the decor tries really hard but comes off more as a Mel's Diner or Lori's Cafe than a mid-30s watering hole.  I think much of this is due to the terrible lighting.  Turn it down boys, no one wants to put on sunglasses to walk into a bar at midnight (or ever...).  The lighting feels more like Aisle 6 at Wal-Mart than an intimate cocktail lounge - and I'm pretty sure lighting this bright didn't even exist in that era.  While I have come to loathe them, these guys could do with some Edison bulbs.

It is obvious that the team has put a lot of thought into the decor and has done some work to bring in interesting period pieces and replica fixtures, but at the end of the day, it's all just too shiny and new to effectively convince anyone that they've stepped back in time.  (If you want to see a bar that does this seamlessly, check out Dear Irving in NYC).

And finally, there is this weird thing going on with the semi-opaque portholes in the restroom doors.  First, who puts semi-opaque portholes in exposed restroom doors?  I don't want to see the silhouette of the dude from the corner peeing...or worse.  And I CERTAINLY don't want the entire bar to have the ability to see me in ANY way while using the restroom.  But then there's the weird blue glow of these odd portholes.  I watched it while we sipped our cocktails and was never able to figure out why it went on or off, but it did and I found it not only very strange but also highly distracting.

Maybe this is a better spot for pre-dinner drinks as it is very quiet and empty, apparently all the time.  But if you're looking for an intimate spot to enjoy a fantastic cocktail there are about 100 better places in SF.
author: Stacy H.

description:
Charming! A change from the octopus dive bar that I can get behind. (Although I did like the octo.) Old timey and clean and quiet. 

Perfect drink in cute glassware too!
author: Barbra I.

description: This is a cute, stylish, 1920s decor neighborhood bar with a lovely selection of cocktails.  We had a couple martinis and they were both tasty and just strong enough without being over the top.  I will be back!
author: Maile N.

description: What a cool little spot that takes you back in time and feels like the Twilight Zone. The staff is very friendly and attentive. The drinks are unique and delicious. Went on a weekend around 10 pm for a couple hours, and was just the right amount of crowd, as you could still hear your conversations.
author: S A.

description:
Super disappointed coming here on a Saturday night around 10p. Everyone was 50+ years old and barely any people inside. 

Place looks more like Mel's Diner.
author: CL S.

description:
Having read a number of articles from connections in Bay Area about the opening of this post-Prohibition bar, I made a point to check it out after a long work weekend. My traveling companion and I got in at 11:30pm on a Sunday, and discovered the definition of perfection.

It's the kind of bar so loaded with atmosphere and style that it doesn't need to be pitch-black to have ambiance - it's just pleasantly dimmed. The streamline modern style is elegant and fresh and truly unique in the world of cocktail bars I've experienced. 

The menu is perfect. Brief, but varied. We each had three drinks (thanks to Uber making that possible) and they were each fantastic. I could easily see myself making a point to travel through the menu, and damn the consequences the next day. The bartender was friendly, attentive and skilled. I'm sure he could have made anything I'd asked for in the way of the classics, but I didn't see much reason to venture off the menu - I'd never had a 20th Century (oh, let's be honest, I'd never even heard of it) and I think it's my new favorite drink. 

I'm bored of dives. I want a beautiful place to drink beautiful drinks, where I can have a good conversation with a date, co-worker or friend - this place is that to a T. If only I had a portal from Portland. I look forward to making it in again!
author: Julie B.

description: Oops, I thought this was supposed to be a 1950's themed bar, but apparently it's 1930's themed? Either way, this place reminded me of a 50s Diner (I guess I'm not the only one according to other reviews). I like how the bartenders dress up in white jackets to play the part, one bartender guy even had the handle bar mustache too and did a funny dance while shaking up a cocktail. It wasn't super packed when we stopped by on a Friday night, which I preferred. Nice little lounge to just sit back and sip on a cocktail over good conversation.
author: Marissa C.

description:
Local watering hole reopened! 
My enthusiasm quickly dissipated when I opened the door and entered the alternate universe of Stookey.. reminiscent of the shining but aesthetically colder and less original. 
Men in white butcher coats arrogantly and overtly ignoring thirsty patrons. 
I was eventually acknowledged and served a lethal cocktail amounting to my iPhone 5 and wallet being lost or stolen..
forcing me to share this crucial message from my desktop  
next time I'm due for a psychological mind f*ck I'll go to ruby sky.
author: Kyle B.

description:
This place is the definition of...OK. I'll admit to being a fairly regular patron of Royal Tug, which was just the right type of fun and casual, everything Stookey's is not. I enjoy this place in an ironic way, as its level of kitsch is fairly commendable really. What I do not enjoy is yet another cocktail bar with the same boring menu and the same slow service. What is so wrong with cheap, good enough, fast-to-serve drinks? 

I will stop in for a laugh every once in a while, and the drinks are fine, but really can't wait for the return of the BAR to San Francisco, as this place is just another version of the plague of artisanal/craft/cocktail arrogance that has ruined nightlife in this City.
author: Preston B.

description:
Listen, I've been happily married for awhile, so my relationship to the bar scene has . . . developed. It's no longer the hunting grounds (I'll show you the notches on my compact later). Now what I want is a quiet place to have a drink, talk, and enjoy the atmosphere, not a noisy, barely-lit cavern filled with shouting techbros drinking the latest $37, 13-shot gimmick called the "Jabba the Mutt" out of wooden buckets painted with the bar's desperate logo-- a graphic smirk, like: "DRANK," perhaps, or "POUND," or maybe "DON'T VOM, BRO." No. If you're looking for a place where you, Matt, Josh, and Tyler can get waaaaaasted after your 14 hour day of coding and playing CoD at Evixxxtion Apps, go elsewhere.

Stookey's Club Moderne is a gorgeously decorated, elegant, art deco beauty with a fantastic menu of no-nonsense vintage cocktails, beautifully crafted by co-owner Tim Stookey, a well-known SF bartender who earned his renown tending bar at the Presidio Social Club, and his excellent staff. The bar's post-prohibition decor is on point-- every tiny detail has been attended to. LOOK UP AT THE LIGHT FIXTURES. Look at the molding. If, like me, you were happy to spend an hour in line for Tower of Terror because you needed more time to look at the decor, you'll be happy here. Unlike Tower of Terror, however, (and too many bars to mention) Stookey's Club Moderne is pristine. Everything's clean, sleek, and gorgeous-- even the bartenders are spiffy and elegant in white coats and ties. 

The bartenders are friendly and knowledgeable. Stookey himself is one of the city's experts in vintage cocktails, and that's reflected in the menu, full of well-known vintage drinks like the Highball, as well as lesser-known drinks that well deserve a comeback, such as the Sazerac. My favorite part of the menu, though, has to be the fact that the non-alcoholic beverages are listed as "Temperance Drinks." See what I mean? On. Point.

If you want to experience post-prohibition, 1930s San Francisco, have a beautiful, vintage cocktail at a reasonable price, and a nice, quiet chat with a friend or six, this is the place.
author: Melissa H.

description:
Flew up to the Bay area for a wedding and decided to check out the 1930's vibe in lower Nob Hill, at Stookey's Club Moderne. Oh my word! I was totally charmed by this cozy elegant lounge. My taste buds were in heaven from delicious cocktails. The ambiance, the many classy, beautifully dressed people in period dress, the sleek lines, the authentic 1930's touches, it was all quite charming . 
OK, now down to the drinks: I tried a good number of the cocktails with my friend - all delicious. I started with the Aviation. Oh, that creme de violette was wonderful, and the lavender blue cocktail in the period glassware enhanced the experience. The 20th Century, Blood and Sand, Pan American Clipper, Corpse Reviver #2 and the Brunelle followed throughout the evening. Top three for me were the Brunelle, Corpse Reviver & the Aviation, but all the drinks were very good. My friend & I noticed all the period piece decor and architectural touches inside the bar, which was easy to do with the comfortably dimmed light (this is not a dark, loud bar). There is period 1930's music playing in the background. I like to be able to see people, architectural lines & artwork, and hear conversation over drinks in bars, so the atmosphere was good for me. The bartenders were dressed elegantly in white. Service was good. The evening was delightful, and I was very sad to have to leave early on a Saturday night, to take the last BART train across the bay. I will return here again on my next trip to SF. In the meantime, I'm heading to BevMo to try to track down some creme de violette. :-)
author: Elizabeth W.

description:
The namesake of Club Moderne, Stookey, has been tending bars in SF for years, first at the Hotel Majestic (back when they had a bar), then later at the Presidio Social Club, and this place definitely reflects his personality. Long before the mustachioed mixologist set existed, Stookey was extolling the virtues of exotic mixers and obscure pre-Prohibition recipes.  Because of this, Stookey is considered a bartender's bartender, and it certainly shows in the drinks served here.

If you are looking for a quiet spot to have a relaxing drink, Stookey's is the place for you.  If you want a drink made by people who take cocktails as seriously as Michelin star chefs take food, Stookey's is the place for you. If you can't stand sports bars or night clubs, Stookey's is the place for you.
author: Dave S.

description: solid cocktail bar with strong drinks and a cool vibe! we stuck with the classics on our first go - sazerac and the barrel aged negroni - both very well made. reasonably priced for the quality - and it seems that there were quite a few regulars on a friday evening, and it wasnt really crowded at all, which is a HUGE plus. i'll be back to try the rest of the menu - especially the aviation.
author: Christina L.

description: i love stookey's, it's like time travel! And don't forget about LIVE ACOUSTIC JAZZ every 3rd Thursday -no cover! wow!
author: pazzo m.

description:
It's been a long, cold winter (note for readers in the far future: that's a lie) and I've spent many evenings in search of an Irish coffee (another note: this is true). Fruitlessly I have searched, denied time and again by unrestocked coffee filters, broken machines. I've sulked over hot toddies far too often this winter. 

So, luckily, the bartenders at Stookey's make the best Irish coffee in San Francisco. Don't think of Buena Vista, where they combine crap ingredients that are bad for you into something delicious. This is a thoughtfully constructed drink. It's transcendent. And not too sweet.

'Thoughtful' really does describe the bar. The lighting in particular is lovely; bright for a bar but soft and flattering. The drink menu is classic, the bartenders are great, and the location avoids a lot of zones full of people I don't like. So...another Irish coffee, please.
author: Connor Skye R.

description: I met the owners at Castlewood Country Club when they came to the club and they were not members, but I still served them.  We had so much fun talking and they were the nicest people!!  They invited me and my husband to come to the bar.  We will be coming on the 17th around 10 to 11 pm.  I hope they will be there!! I remember Tim (?) I think his name was and his girlfriend or wife.  It's been a while, but we are finally coming to the city on Wednesday night after a concert at the Fillmore.  I hope to see them both!!  --Cheri
author: Cheri R.

description: Great find, was not going to walk in from the looks of the outside, but wow, awesome inside, small craft cocktail bar, well dressed "master mixologist" and great service!
author: Andy K.

description: My girlfriend and I really enjoyed this bar because it's not too crowded or loud. It was more of a lounge bar with some sophisticated beverages to choose from. Bar stools are comfy and the bartender was very courteous and talented.
author: LJ V.

description: Love this bar!! The drinks were amazing and presented in such an old era way that is definitely lost in todays world. I especially adored the mix of 1920's-1940's music they had playing, not like the top 40 crap (that a child could write) that's played in most establishments. The atmosphere was unique and very calming. Definitely coming back! We enjoyed the 12 Mile Limit, Southside Fizz, and an Irish Coffee. All made to perfection. :)
author: Mary S.

description: First time I've been to San Francisco. We just happened to walk by this place. Not only is the place super cute! (50's classy vibe) but the bar tenders are super friendly! They recommend great San Francisco favorite drinks, and my friend and I loved it! Totally worth checking out!
author: Meggan S.

description: I had two cocktails and they were great. I go to a lot of cocktail bars and I was pretty impressed. The bartender was really friendly and the bar was not as dark as a cave. It felt really clean and happy. I love me some dark bars, but it was nice for a change to see my friend I was talking to and be able to have a conversation in the little bar.
author: Geoff G.

description: Fancy cocktails and a neat menu for the holidays. Bartender is quick and professional. Wouldn't mind checking it out again for other drinks, especially since it's right in our neighbourhood.
author: Cassandra J.

description:
Stookey's, located on the same block as my apartment, is a welcome addition to the neighborhood. 

10pm, Saturday night: 5 of us walk into this simple, yet engaging bar. We are able to immediately grab a table. We review the menu: it's full of oldies-but-goodies: Sazerac, Aviation, Moscow Mule, etc. Just two men are working the whole place and it takes them a while to take our order and make our drinks. 15 minutes later, the drinks come out: Moscow Mule: ginger beer, vodka and lime in perfect harmony; Aviation: as sultry and mysterious as it needs to be; 100 Reasons to Rye: if you like rye, you'll love this one. 

A little about ambiance; the decorations and color scheme are a bit "arctic." The music is lively, but quiet - a great place to have a conversation. The bartenders are dressed in white coats and take their craft very seriously.

My only issue with Stookey's was the slowness of service. Besides us, there were maybe 10 others in the bar, but it took 30 minutes for us to get our drinks from the moment we sat down. I can imagine that if the bar got any busier, this problem would only escalate. 

All in all, I'm very happy to have a neighborhood bar of this caliber and I hope they scale up their operation as the demand rises, as it certainly will.
author: Liza K.

description: Go Stookey, old chap.  You've done it. Got your own bar finally.  To drink your magical concoctions under the roof of your very own business has been a long time coming.  My darling and I will be back again... And again... And keep those complimentary nuts going.
author: Lisa J.

description: Great bar that has a diner like feel to it. Bartenders were very generous and loved the vibe!
author: Anurag K.

description: We just left here after 30 plus minutes and receiving one drink out of a two drink order.  This place is very under-staffed.  They messed up my drink order and served my husband a pretty weak Sazerac.  I waited another 10-15 minutes without the correct drink being provided,  we just paid for his drink and left.  Very disappointing.
author: Kathryn V.

description: Fantastic classy bar. Great ambiance, nice drink menu.
author: Elisabeth T.

description: Delicious takes on classic cocktails in a beautiful and nostalgic setting.
author: Tim A.

description: One of the best little gems in the city when it comes to outstanding cocktails and unique ambience. The art deco details are seriously on point, and the cocktails are amazing! The "Champs Ulysses" and "Pisco Punch" are to die for. Not to be missed in SF.
author: Joe M.

description: Love this small cool place.  As a tourist we wanted the local flavor and this is it. And very reasonable priced drinks.
author: Howard M.

description: My friends and I met at Club Moderne on the urging of another friend who is infatuated with all things 20's and 30's. The bar was gorgeous! Every little detail really spoke to the time period from the matchbooks held in little Art Deco holders to the glassware the drinks were presented in.The menu was a bit foreign since I'm not a big drinker. We all ordered something different and sipped off each others drinks. Each drink was distinctly different and had complex, Rich flavors. We had a corpse reviver ( yum! ), aviation ( pretty! ), Mai tai ( flavorful! ), Jack and rose ( my least fav ) and a strawberry slow gin fizz ( double yum! ). The drinks were strong and when I got tipsy quickly we were even given complimentary Cheezits. If you want to take a step back in time take a detour to club moderne. I felt strange even having a cell phone at a place like this.....I think I hear the cops now, going to shut this place down for prohibition! Ssh it's our little secret.
author: Sarah I.

description: Awesome atmosphere and delicious drinks. Definitely will be coming back! Ordered the "Old Cuban" and it was excellent. Not too sweet but certainly strong. Try this place out you're in the area!
author: Nick C.

description: Fantastic cocktails and a friendly vibe plus a warm bartender = recipe for returning for tasting of new craft cocktails asap
author: Brian S.

description: Words can not describe these cocktails. These are the most unique and interesting drinks I have ever had the pleasure of trying. The bartender is like a mad scientist with the flair of a magician. If you have the chance to stop in for a drink or 10, do not pass up the opportunity. I wish I could give a suggestion for my favorite drink but everything that we tried was even better then the last. Just do it, you will not be disappointed.
author: Michael M.

description: A delightful cocktail lounge reminiscent of the 1930's. Cocktails served  by uniformed mixologist. Cocktails served u will only find in an "Old Mr Bostons" bar guide.
author: Jim B.

description: Great little spot!  Fantastic selection of time honored, classic boozy cocktails.  Retro in design, with the bartenders playing the part, curly mustaches and all.  Quiet, clean, and a large selection of drinks you have probably forgotten about (I mean, they actually have a blood and sand on the menu!).  The only downfall is that the prices are just a tad steep, IMHO.  I think the drink that makes me believe this was the negroni.  I love negroni's...but $14?  Maybe its part of the ingredients that they use for their version?  But a negroni is 3 ingredients, and I can get a nice, self respecting negroni at other bars in downtown SF for about $9.  Regardless, a cool spot that I intend to visit again, if only sparingly.
author: T. G.

description: When you walk into Stookey's it's like walking back in time. The 1920's decor, the bartender's garb and drinks are classic. My favorite drinks are the corpse recover and aviation. It's a place where you can have a nice drink and have a good conversation with the barkeep or your neighbor.
author: Kristy F.

description: Excellent cocktails whipped up by bartenders with the white jackets on, in a nicely sized uber art deco space. A refreshing change from the distressed metal/wood look and fixie-riding handle-bar mustachioed mixologists. This is now in the regular rotation along with Hi-Lo club on Polk and Tradition on Jones.
author: Eric T.

description:
I actually love the idea of this place but the bartenders need some serious training on how to act like human beings. I went here on a Friday night and at first maybe 5 people in the entire bar. It takes forever for them to make drinks because these are "artisan" cocktails I guess and yes, they are good if you don't mind waiting 20 minutes for a drink to be made. 

The thing that seriously irked me was a 2nd bartender showed up later in the evening (this was around 7 pm). I think she spent 15 minutes fluffing up her cocktail toothpicks before she even talked to anyone. I had been there for a while and some people came in after me and she took their drink order while I was still sitting there. I had finished my first drink and nobody asked me if I needed anything so I asked Ms. Cranky Pants if she would make me something when she had time... lol. I got such a nasty reply that the 1st bartender (who was busy with some other folks) came over to rescue me and tell me he would make my drink. 

So I decided to stay and another ice age passed, I finished my 2nd drink and nobody asked me if I would like anything else or if a check was needed. I actually stood in line at the cash register before anyone noticed I was dying to leave. 

Never coming back here again, the waitstaff needs a lesson in manners and how to treat people. There were 2 bartenders and never more than 8 people in the place the entire time I was there.
author: Amy O.

description: This place is stylish and cool. Great mix of customers and the drinks menu is frankly unparalleled in the city. Great but small selection of beer and sparkling or still wines (seven offered by the glass, as far as I could count).  The cocktails are the story here, though.
author: Ross S.

description:
Genteel, elegant, gorgeous, well-lit, and great early 20th century music playing quietly in the background. The owners deeply care about their bar and about their customers' experience. The cocktail list is carefully curated without a lick of pretension, all the pretty glassware is vintage of the era, and the white-jacketed bartenders are experts at what they do. This place has become my "local pub" in San Francisco, which is saying something when one considers the loads of great bars in the City. They also have WiFi if you need it. Never change, Stookey's.

I also attended a small wedding reception here, and the owners were AMAZING in taking care of the couple. If you are getting married at City Hall, this place is just a quick ride away.
author: Monica H.

description: I wanted to try this place out-I read a review and heard it was groovy and retro (gotta love the name) However, we walked in and felt that we were in a weird pharmacy out of a 50s movie (none of these things are good). The lighting is extra-wrong. The vibe is not welcoming or fun and the bartender's "lab coat" it seemed gave it an extra creepy vibe. All and all--this may have sounded great on paper but the execution of the bar is just off and needs to be retooled to have a human touch and an element of fun, not feel like a  sterile movie set.
author: Janice C.

description:
I've hesitated to write this review worrying that too many good reviews might drive crowds up (like if it became 'hip' over night).  However, in fairness to the outstanding bartenders and the beautiful club, itself, I owe it to them.  

Cocktails are meticulously crafted to splendiferous effect!  Subtle, delicious flavors abound.  I absolutely ADORE the '30's theming, right down to the starched, pressed, white jackets of the bartenders. 

I also adore that I can hear my friends as we chat.  There's no yelling necessary at Club Modern.  '30's period music plays in the background enough to add to the ambience, but not enough to drown out conversation.  

I liked this place when it was Tug & Yacht (who doesn't love a giant squid in the overhead attacking miniature ships?) and was worried about what might follow.  All fears completely abated: I like Club Modern even more! 

Hopefully next time I go I'll still be able to get a seat ;) !
author: Margret C.

description: Best bar ever, I'm conflicted to tell everyone to come here because it's our little neighborhood secret but it just doesn't get better than this. Fabulous deco interior, top notch drinks and some of the most gregarious barkeeps I've ever encountered. Great selection of whiskers, gins and what have you. House cocktails will amaze. I come here at least a couple days, every week. Please don't crash the party too hard but if your enjoy a classy cocktail and great conversation, roll on by.
author: Trevor M.

description: The place is really nice and well decorated a nice upgrade from the original dive bar that was there. The blood and sand cocktail was nice but spot is very popular and service can be slow.
author: N A.

description: Great drinks and service. The bartenders were true professionals. But if I can give the owner/operators just one piece of sorely needed advice: TURN THE LIGHTS DOWN! I thoroughly enjoyed my drinks, but it felt like I was drinking in a hospital operating room.
author: Bobby N.

description: The ambiance is classy and cool with vintage flair throughout the bar and big band style music playing in the background. The bartenders are friendly and quick with recommendations; the drinks are classic and expertly made. We loved the experience and look forward to many more visits!
author: Meagan S.

description: It's the violet hour. You've picked the right place. Your shirt and shave are fresh. Your tie's just right and your cuffs are linked. You're giving a tug to your pocket square when she walks in and cozies up next to you at the bar. "What's yours?" The white-jacketed barman delivers two perfect cocktails for the beginning of a perfect evening.
author: Mark R.

description: Super cool atmosphere! The drinks were amazing and the glasses were so throw back. My husband got the Aviation and it has a sour yummy bite at the end. I got the blood and sand and it was very smooth! Next time we visit San Francisco we  return!
author: Ashton S.

description: I love this place! Beautiful decor and colors that matches the era perfectly. Delicious, hand crafted cocktails. Very enjoyable and comfortable place. Look forward to going back!!
author: Kristen P.

description: Cocktails at this place are top notch. We went there during the first week after they opened. Their bartenders were very friendly. The interior is decent.
